designations.source: A review of the Hemiptera of Great Britain: The Aquatic and Semi-aquatic Bugs
designations.source_description: This report was commissioned to update the national status of aquatic and semi-aquatic bugs using IUCN methodology for assessing threat. It covers all species of aquatic and semi-aquatic bugs (Heteroptera) in Great Britain, identifying those that are rare and/or under threat as well as non-threatened and non-native species. A.A. Cook November 2015.
designations.reporting_category: Red listing based on 2001 IUCN guidelines
designations.designation_description: A taxon is Not Evaluated when it is has not yet been evaluated against the criteria
designations.comments: Most modern records from N. Ireland where it was first recorded in the early 1900's (biodiversityireland). Recent records from Notts in 2002 (R. Merritt, pers. comm.) and Cumbria in 2000 (Read, 2001). it is a breeding species in Ireland, but always occurs in low numbers (Brian Nelson pers. comm.). Low numbers in England may indicate under-recording but it is a conspicuous species and there is no evidence of a breeding population - probably an occasional immigrant.
